"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow 0^i=\cos(\ln(0))+i\sin(\ln(0))"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
And as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln(0)=\red{undefined}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow 0^i=\red{undefined}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now let's consider "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=a+bi;b\neq0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^z=0^a\times0^{bi}=0\times(0^i)^b=0\times(\red{undefined})^b=\red{undefined}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \Im(z)\cancel{\in}(-\infty,0)\cup(0,\infty)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now let's consider "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z=a+0\times i=a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow \Im(z)=0,\space z\in\mathbb{R}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow 0^z=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0^z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not a undefined value then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Im(z)=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 0 X 2 = 0
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There is a king. He visits 4 temples one after another in his kingdom along with some of his followers. Each temple has 100 stairs. Upon reaching the gate of the first temple, he says, "Keep one coin on each stair as you move upwards. Give half of the remaining coins to the head of the temple. Repeat the same process as you come down and when you reach the point where you started off, give half of the remaining coins to the temple officials there." This whole process is followed for all temples. But his followers say that when they came down from the last temple and gave half of the remaining coins to the officials, they were left with nothing."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Calculate the original number of coins the king had."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint- Read the Title (Carefully) if you think that the problem is wrong!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is a part of my set Different!"}]}]}

at the top of the first step, he will have  (x-100)/2 coins. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
now  remove 100 from this and it becomes (x-100-200)/4 coins.
Now the denominator is not of any use as the final amount is  zero.
now x would be  100+200+400+800+1600+3200+6400+12800=25500
The reason is that at each temple he loses coins twice and as he  has to give half of it to the pundit and the officials.
so,at each temple the lost coins is 2 times i.e. 2  powers of 2 .
so we have 100(2^0+2^1+2^3+2^4+2^5+2^6+2^7)=25500"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We see that the king exhausts his last coin coming down the stairs of the last temple.  So run the videotape backwards: he finishes with 0 coins.  That means he had 100 coins at the top of the last temple after he gave half away.  Which means he 200 coins when he reached the top, before giving half away.  Which means he had 300 before climbing the stairs.  Which means he had 600 before giving half to the followers of the third temple, etc."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simplifying:
Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(x) = x+100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"g(x) = 2x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Each temple requires two alternating applications of g and f. 
Thus, we are looking for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(g(f(g(f(g(f(g(f(g(f(g(f(g(f(g(0))))))))))))))))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
Or, if that's too much of a mouthful, let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"h(x) = f(g(x)) = 2x+100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  We're looking for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"h^8(0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 10 million Accounts Puzzle, 1,000 followers problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Have you ever wondered how brilliant started?  Well, here's the story of brilliant from its roots.  Be like Sherlock Holmes and read carefully, there are clues to this problem scattered throughout the story, some are quite well hidden.  I have bolded one part which may have been too hard to catch.  Most of the info in this story is true except the parts about Daniel, Prasun, Brilliant's start date (I changed this for convenience) and the staff incident.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume today is May 11st.  Exactly 2.5 years ago (Nov. 11th), Calvin, Sue, and Peter got together to form a site to attract the smartest kids in the world, each made his/her own account.  Luring them not with rewards, but with intriguing challenges submitted by other users from around the world, Brilliant began to grow.  The next day, Daniel, being the genius he was, became the first person to join this new site.  He began making thousands of the best problems the all knowing Gods of this universe had ever seen."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Unfortunately, that same day, Prasun, while "},{"type":"text","text":"trolling people on Omeggle","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":", saw an ad for a math website by the title "brilliant.org".  He moved most of his trolling focus from Omeggle to Brilliant and the growth rate drastically slowed down.  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also on that very day, Calvin, being the math God he is, correctly hypothesized that Brilliant's growth rate would take the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{\# of accounts}=\lfloor a\cdot 5^{bx}+c\rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are constants, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a,c "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are integers, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the amount of time (measured in months) elapsed from Nov. 11th.  Unfortunately, he had to change it when Prasun the troll joined to the new growth rate  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\text{\# of accounts}=\lfloor a\cdot e^{bx}+c\rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the natural logarithm base."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Many moons passed and brilliant continued to grow at the exponential rate law mentioned immediately above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"One groggy Thursday morning while Peter was dozing off at his desk, Silas burst into the room screaming at the top of his lungs, "We did it! We hit 1 million accounts!".  Peter, alarmed, immediately woke up to see a jubilant Silas on the other side of his work cubical.  Silas began to run around the room and Aaron soon joined him.  David walked into the room after hearing all the commotion only to see a smiling Silas and equally joyful Aaron barreling down the isle straight towards him.  BAM!  The three collided in what can only be described as "the second Big Bang".  After the stars disappeared from the three Stooges' eyes, David realized his phone was broken.  Being the physics genius he is, he immediately began to calculate how much force was required to break his phone's 1/32 inch thick anodized aluminum backplate.  At the same time, Silas and Aaron promised to buy David a new phone since Christmas was coming up in 14 days."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As days turned to weeks and weeks to months, Brilliant became swamped  with even more new members.  Sue realized that Brilliant needed more staff members so she posted "},{"type":"text","text":" this note ","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" looking for more people to hire.  In this note, she stated that Brilliant had 1.4 million accounts.  However, this was actually a slight miscount due to technical errors.  Today, May 11th, 2015, Brilliant finally reached exactly 1.4 million accounts. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Based on the information given above, in which month and year will Brilliant reach 10 million accounts? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For simplicity's sake, assume all months have 30 days. "}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The floor function is just for "technical correctness" (you can't have 10.5 accounts).  You don't need it in your calculations as it won't affect the result (assuming it's correct) by more than a day. And even being 7 days off won't affect your answer. "}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You may use a computer for equation solving.  When working with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", I suggest using at the least the ten-thousandths place,."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 million is the number one followed by 6 zeros."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that in reality, my prediction is that it might take a little longer to reach 10 million accounts than the actual answer to this question suggests."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is my unofficial 1000 followers problem.  I don't know how much attention it will get because it's a new type of problem.  Tell me how you like it and I might make another one. So please, if I may ask, do take the time to at least read it."}]}]}
